root.label: Cell Morphology
root.description: After confirming Gram positive stain, determine the shape of the cells under the microscope.
root.question: What is the cell morphology of your Gram positive organism?

catalase.label: Catalase Test
catalase.description: Add a drop of 3% hydrogen peroxide to a colony. Bubbling (O₂ release) = positive. Catalase breaks down H₂O₂ into water and oxygen.
catalase.question: What is the result of the catalase test?

coagulase.label: Coagulase Test
coagulase.description: Mix colony with rabbit plasma. Clot formation = positive. Coagulase-positive staphylococci can clot fibrinogen.
coagulase.question: What is the result of the coagulase test?

result_aureus.label: Staphylococcus aureus
result_aureus.description: Gram positive, catalase positive, coagulase positive. A major human pathogen; causes skin infections, pneumonia, endocarditis, and toxic shock syndrome. Often displays golden-yellow colonies.

novobiocin.label: Novobiocin Sensitivity
novobiocin.description: Place a novobiocin disk on the plate. A zone of inhibition ≥ 16 mm = sensitive. Differentiates coagulase-negative Staphylococcus species.
novobiocin.question: What is the result of the novobiocin sensitivity test?

result_epidermidis.label: Staphylococcus epidermidis
result_epidermidis.description: Gram positive, catalase positive, coagulase negative, novobiocin sensitive. Common skin commensal; clinically significant in immunocompromised patients and prosthetic device infections.

result_saprophyticus.label: Staphylococcus saprophyticus
result_saprophyticus.description: Gram positive, catalase positive, coagulase negative, novobiocin resistant. Common cause of urinary tract infections in young sexually active women.

hemolysis.label: Hemolysis on Blood Agar
hemolysis.description: Observe colony growth on sheep blood agar. Alpha (α) = partial/green hemolysis. Beta (β) = complete clear hemolysis. Gamma (γ) = no hemolysis.
hemolysis.question: What type of hemolysis is observed on blood agar?

optochin.label: Optochin Sensitivity
optochin.description: Place an optochin (P) disk on the plate. Zone of inhibition ≥ 14 mm = sensitive. Optochin differentiates S. pneumoniae from viridans streptococci.
optochin.question: What is the result of the optochin sensitivity test?

result_pneumoniae.label: Streptococcus pneumoniae
result_pneumoniae.description: Gram positive, catalase negative, alpha hemolytic, optochin sensitive. Leading cause of community-acquired pneumonia, meningitis, and otitis media. Colonies are characteristically lancet-shaped diplococci.

result_viridans.label: Viridans Streptococci
result_viridans.description: Gram positive, catalase negative, alpha hemolytic, optochin resistant. A diverse group of streptococci; normal oral flora. Can cause subacute bacterial endocarditis in susceptible patients.

bacitracin.label: Bacitracin Sensitivity
bacitracin.description: Place a bacitracin (A) disk on the plate. Any zone of inhibition = sensitive. Differentiates Group A from Group B Streptococcus.
bacitracin.question: What is the result of the bacitracin sensitivity test?

result_pyogenes.label: Streptococcus pyogenes
result_pyogenes.description: Gram positive, catalase negative, beta hemolytic, bacitracin sensitive. Group A Streptococcus. Causes strep throat, impetigo, scarlet fever, and rheumatic fever. PYR positive.

result_agalactiae.label: Streptococcus agalactiae
result_agalactiae.description: Gram positive, catalase negative, beta hemolytic, bacitracin resistant. Group B Streptococcus. Important cause of neonatal meningitis and sepsis; screened in pregnant women.

bile_esculin.label: Bile Esculin + 6.5% NaCl Tolerance
bile_esculin.description: Bile esculin agar: darkening = positive. 6.5% NaCl broth: turbidity = growth. Enterococci are bile esculin positive AND salt tolerant.
bile_esculin.question: Are both bile esculin AND 6.5% NaCl tests positive?

result_enterococcus.label: Enterococcus spp.
result_enterococcus.description: Gram positive, catalase negative, gamma hemolytic, bile esculin positive, salt tolerant. Common in the GI tract; causes UTIs and endocarditis. Notorious for antibiotic resistance (VRE).

result_strep_group_d.label: Non-enterococcal Group D Streptococcus
result_strep_group_d.description: Gram positive, catalase negative, gamma hemolytic, bile esculin positive but NOT salt tolerant (6.5% NaCl negative). Includes S. bovis / S. gallolyticus. Associated with colorectal carcinoma.

spore.label: Endospore Stain
spore.description: Find the endospore stain procedure in the lab manual. We will use the microwave proceedure.
spore.question: Are endospores present in the rod-shaped organism?

oxygen.label: Oxygen Requirements
oxygen.description: If an organism is strictly anaerobic, it will not grow in the presence of oxygen.
oxygen.question: What are the oxygen requirements of the spore-forming rod?

result_bacillus.label: Bacillus spp.
result_bacillus.description: Gram positive, endospore-forming, aerobic rod. Includes B. anthracis (anthrax), B. cereus (food poisoning), and B. subtilis (common lab saprophyte). Spores are highly resistant to heat and chemicals.

result_clostridium.label: Clostridium spp.
result_clostridium.description: Gram positive, endospore-forming, anaerobic rod. Includes C. difficile (antibiotic-associated colitis), C. botulinum (botulism), C. tetani (tetanus), and C. perfringens (gas gangrene).

result_listeria.label: Listeria monocytogenes
result_listeria.description: Gram positive, non-spore-forming, motile rod (tumbling motility at 25°C). Causes listeriosis; particularly dangerous in pregnant women, neonates, and immunocompromised individuals. Cold tolerant — grows in refrigerator temperatures.

catalase_rod.label: Catalase Test
catalase_rod.description: Find the catalase test in the lab manual. We will use the slide method.
catalase_rod.question: Is the organism catalase positive or negative?

result_corynebacterium.label: Corynebacterium spp.
result_corynebacterium.description: Gram positive, non-spore-forming, non-motile, catalase positive rod. Characteristically club-shaped ("Chinese letter" arrangement). C. diphtheriae causes diphtheria; C. jeikeium is a nosocomial pathogen.

result_lactobacillus.label: Lactobacillus spp.
result_lactobacillus.description: Gram positive, non-spore-forming, non-motile, catalase negative rod. Normal flora of the vagina and GI tract. Produces lactic acid; important in fermentation. Generally low pathogenicity.
